author: Martin Owens
message:
I ripped my entire DVD collection last year, 128 discs using handbreak (and 12 computers all in parallel). I've basically got the process of ripping all the discs in mkv, with sub titles, multiple audio tracks (for anime and foreign dubs) with good sizes and quick codecs. I tried a few programs, but handbreak just seems to be a very good system.

Now about these 99 titles, when I see these, I run the DVD through vlc and find the title that the menu would play and then grab that one. Now all my movies and TV run through xbmc really nicely.

Do we have an Ubuntu multimedia club to talk about these kinds of things?

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message:
12 computers all in parallel, wow! Now that's a professional ripping setup :)

I did exactly what you said regarding the 99 titles: played the DVD with vlc, note the title number.

Thinking a bit more about my experience, I probably would have known about HandBrake, had it been in Ubuntu archives. I assume the fact it ships with its own copies of many libs is the reason why it is not there.

author: Anaximander
message: I personally use handbrake and makemkv under linux for ripping my dvds and blurays for use with my dlna server. While makemkv ist not free it does a good job not only on blurays but also on most dvds. For now it seems there's only one (Mad about you, Season1) which I can't rip at all.

replies.author: Martin Owens
replies.message:
handbreak can make mkvs and the mkv tools in ubuntu (mmv etc) are very good.

Also useful is avidemux which does a nice job of converting sub/vob titles into srt subtitles, useful for then combining into the mkv for real nice looking titles in xbmc.

author: Roger
message: What I do is just copy the entire DVD as is. This does take more space since you aren't transcoding, but it means you keep all the special features, menus etc. It also only takes about 10 minutes. You just need to use lsdvd or similar to list the disc contents which will then enable the correct CSS descrambling.

replies.author: Aurélien
replies.message: I prefer to have individual files (I also rip the short movies separately) because it is easier for the kids to navigate the movie collection through XBMC, which provide a consistent interface rather than having then learn their way in each DVD menus.
